results.title: Energetically yours
results.creator_credit: David Hilberman, Walter Lowendahl and Transfilm
results.brief_description: An animated film by Ronald Searle which traces man’s search for sources of energy to help him in his daily life. It tells of our need and use of energy since primitive times - from fire, through coal and oil, to the atom.
results.description: An animated film by Ronald Searle which traces man’s search for sources of energy to help him in his daily life. It tells of our need and use of energy since primitive times - from fire, through coal and oil, to the atom.

results.title: Endocrine glands: how they affect you
results.brief_description: Shows the location of endocrine glands in the human body and explains how hormones secreted by these glands affect growth, metabolism, sexual development, and behaviour. Discusses the use of animal hormones in the treatment of human diseases.

results.title: 'Endeavour'
results.brief_description: H.M.N.Z.S. Endeavour takes the New Zealand party for the British Trans-Antarctic Expedition to the Antarctic. Members of the party carry out oceanographic research, help build Scott Base and restore Scott’s and Shackleton’s huts before the ship brings Sir Vivian Fuchs, Sir Edmund Hillary and other expedition members back to New Zealand

results.title: The End of the Nancy J.
results.creator_credit: Bernard Devlin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Bill Cluney’s fishing boat, the ”Nancy J”, is unsafe. Pleas by a marine engineer to make it safe are ignored. Then Bill becomes frightened by the local undertaker’s interest in him as a high death risk, and he begins to install safety equipment. But before the repairs are completed, Bill sets out to sea and the ”Nancy J” explodes. Cast includes: Stan Kane, James Barron, Donald Young and Len Watt

results.title: The End of summer
results.creator_credit: Michel Brault and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Filmed at a summer cottage in the Laurentians north of Montreal, this film penetrates briefly the charmed world of the adolescent. Watching and listening, you sense the bittersweet mood of childhood’s end, the poignant awareness that nothing will ever be the same after this summer at the lake. With English subtitles. (Award: New York)

results.title: The End of one
results.brief_description: A wordless parable of modern society in which masses of seagulls fighting for growing mounds of garbage are intercut with the final feeble movements of a single dying bird while tractors and jet planes roar in the distance

results.title: End of a summers day
results.creator_credit: Robert Fortier, Don Rennick, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A comment without words on the ancient theme of love and war: the man called to arms for his country; his sweetheart left behind to mourn; sorrow and separation visited upon the innocent. This is how it has always been, but implicit in the film are the protests of a new generation: Must it always be so? Is not love better than war? Cast includes: Michel Gauthier, Dennis Nadeau, Caroline Price, Paul Sullivan. (Award: New York)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Fortier, Don Rennick, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Encounter
results.creator_credit: Dept of Agriculture, Vic and Victoria. Ministry of Aboriginal Affairs
results.brief_description: Lake Tyers was the site of a ten day multi-cultural camp for boys. Under the watchful eyes of voluntary skilled instructors the boys swam, sailed, canoed, scuba-dived, went hiking, fishing and played the residents at cricket. They made friends and learned teamwork and co-operation. Narrated by David Johnson.

results.title: Encounter Bay
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Shepherd and S A Government Tourist Bureau
results.brief_description: Encounter Bay, where the Murray River enters the sea, has a colorful history of whaling stations and ship wrecks. Bleached bones, rusty anchors, and museums remain to testify. Now Victor Harbour, Port Elliot, and Goolwa are popular holiday resorts. Luxurious accomodation, miles of surf beaches, golf courses, and natural beauty have made it a playground for people of all ages.

results.title: The Encircling sea
results.brief_description: No part of New Zealand is very far from the sea and as a result it has become part of the lives of the inhabitants. Many are engaged in the fishing industry; boating and sailing are popular pastimes; and the numerous beaches within easy reach of the city dweller, provide opportunities for swimming and relaxation.
